website_summaries.verdict: A non-academic, accessible computer science guide to the fundamentals that every programmer should know.
pros: A painless introduction to the core concepts of computer science that are useful for any level
Gentle and helpful couple chapters dedicated to Math
This book does a great job of explaining concepts and giving the reader a broader overview
cons: Some reviewers didn’t like that the examples were given in a pseudocode

customer_reviews.title: A good computer science reference
customer_reviews.text: I am a self-taught python coder, who wanted to learn more about the field without getting bogged down in details for 4 years. So I bought this book to help me get a good overview of major concepts in computer science. The book does a great job of giving the reader a broad overview of computing concepts ranging from time complexity to databases to memory management. It’s a great reference for anyone who wants to expand his/her/their horizons beyond their immediate field of expertise. I found the book easy and fun to read. Also I discovered some concepts that I’d like to explore further. I’d recommend this book to anyone who has gotten into programming from a non-sc background.
customer_reviews.author: Chuck

customer_reviews.title: This book is on point
customer_reviews.text: My first impression was, "this thing is tiny" and it is. It's 160 pages about half an inch thick, but once you dive into the material you realize it's very full of information and it takes a while to digest. I'm 3 hours deep and have only read 27 pages. It cuts right down to the point, exactly as the title describes
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Great introduction to computer architecture, data structures and algorithms.
customer_reviews.text: I enjoyed the information about data structures, algorithms and computer architecture. There are lots of typos in this book, but they won't prevent you from learning some valuable stuff.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: In short, I'm mad I didn't hear about this excellent book sooner.
customer_reviews.text: Every now and then you come across a book that makes you mad you didn't come across it sooner. This is that book. I am a self-taught coder lacking in formal training. As a result, there were large gaps in my knowledge of computer science. I can honestly say this book taught me more than any other book I've read on the subject. Even the concepts I knew going in were clarified and explained simply where I learned something new w/ each section. If you are lacking in formal training (or want something to refresh your training), this book is a must-have. Highly recommend!
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Great use of examples for important concepts
customer_reviews.text: I really like this book. It has a nice soft cover, and I like the use of colorful emojis in the examples. It provides clear and concise introductions to a variety of computer science concepts. I am just getting started on my journey trying to teach myself programming, and this book provides a decent explanation for some entry level concepts that I may have heard of before in passing, but now feel confident enough about to discuss with my friends with actual degrees in CS.
customer_reviews.author: Micah Taylor

customer_reviews.title: I was able to grasp some things I was struggling with when reading more academic books like Skiena or Sedgewick
customer_reviews.text: This reading helped me formalize and internalize concepts that make up fundamentals of so called computer science. I was able to grasp some things I was struggling with when reading more academic books like Skiena or Sedgewick. My professional knowledge mainly comes from experiential learning associated with employment. Reading this book along with practicing LeetCode questions also helped me to get substantially better at Silicon Valley style interviews.
customer_reviews.author: Alexey Solovtsov

customer_reviews.title: Lazy writing, some clear mistakes
customer_reviews.text: I'm not sure why this books is well reviewed. If you are looking for anything beyond an airport fiction kind of explanation of computer science, you won't get it from this book. Things are covered too quickly, at some points with the author even saying google it rather than giving an answer. There were some mistakes in the basic logic section. Overall, really disappointing and shallow take on the topic. I really don't get what need this books fills, other than maybe a middle school student doing a book report on CS or something.
customer_reviews.author: Signify

customer_reviews.title: Great introduction
customer_reviews.text: This book was so helpful - I’m a beginner looking to understand the “low level” computer basics and this book made me want to keep learning more. I read it after watching PBS’ YouTube Crash Course Computer Science series and they each explained the same concepts a bit differently so that nothing fell through the cracks. The databases chapter was more advanced than the rest of the book, so I skimmed it, but I’ll come back to it later after some more learning. The book could use some copy-editing, but a couple of odd grammar and dangling phrases are a price worth paying for great conceptual explanation.
customer_reviews.author: Em B

customer_reviews.title: Good, quick read
customer_reviews.text: This is a very accessible and broad view of computer science concepts. Probably fine to read if you don't have any computing background, but even better if you have a little. Good for students, junior/intermediate developers, and people that work with developers who would like to speak the language a little better (analysts, QA, product, etc). If you have a lot of experience you'll probably be a little underwhelmed (though the book does not pretend to be anything but an introduction). You won't learn a ton about any topic. It's the kind of book that will spark your interest in different topics, so that you can go buy other books in that area.
customer_reviews.author: IronJ

customer_reviews.title: Tons of helpful Computer Science related topics in a very condensed format
customer_reviews.text: I read the book once in a while to refresh my memory of concepts that are important to know but easy to forget due to the extensive wealth of subjects that Computer Science entails. One minor suggestion is, like someone else pointed out in another reviews, it would have been better to show the snippets of code in a language like Python instead of using pseudocode.
customer_reviews.author: Latin Warrior

customer_reviews.title: Great title, great idea, not so good of a book.
customer_reviews.text: The author doesn't seem to communicate effectively. The emojis are cute but add nothing to the book. The examples looked great with colors and charts but unfortunately they did very to little educate. I bought this book because of all the great reviews. To those that got a lot out of this book hats off to you but I just don't see how unless you are a superficial skimmer that doesn't actually read the book but one of those people that intends to read a book but never does however however they are convinced its good from just quickly thumbing through it and reading others reviews. I'd recommend A Common-Sense Guide to Data Structures and Algorithms over this book.

customer_reviews.text: Great book! However it does get a bit lost sometimes going too deep into unnecessary details. It's a great book/reference to have nonetheless.

customer_reviews.title: Disappointed

customer_reviews.title: Good, but could be better.
customer_reviews.text: Being in computer science myself, and programming every day, this book receives a B-. Yes, there is valuable information in it, but the lack of real world code is disappointing. I would buy a new edition of this if it contained code you'd see on the job. -MrNetTek

customer_reviews.title: This is a fun book!

customer_reviews.title: Good, but introductory
customer_reviews.text: This is a great Freshman-level/Computer Science 101 book. It provides an introduction to many ideas. It is also a pretty quick read. However, if you've gone very far in your studies at all, you will quickly surpass the knowledge it contains.

customer_reviews.title: Great distillation of Computer Science
customer_reviews.text: Having taken several CS courses in the last year, I found this book to be an incredible resource for stepping back and looking at the big picture again. In courses, you tend to lose the forest for the trees -- this book is perfect for understanding how the different topics connect with each other. Provides a great introduction to all necessary areas of Computer Science education.
customer_reviews.author: Rahul Nallappa

customer_reviews.title: Improves your thinking
customer_reviews.text: Awesome book. If you are new to programming, read it. It’ll help you think through coding problems and it’ll improve your general thinking skills.
customer_reviews.author: Craig Anthony

customer_reviews.title: I enjoy this book because it teaches about a way of ...
customer_reviews.text: Computer Science is being offered in more and more high schools; however, many of us are not computer science majors. To most, computer science is synonymous with programming. I enjoy this book because it teaches about a way of thinking rather than coding. I believe students need to learn how to think about a problem before they attempt to solve it. The book offers a fresh, simple approach to many computer science concepts.

customer_reviews.author: hapihakr

customer_reviews.title: I would recommend the book for students of any discipline
customer_reviews.text: An easy-to-follow guide through those fundamental principles of computer science that are only hazily grasped or completely unknown to us non-programmers who nevertheless program. Purists may complain about the author's use of emojis. For only a few hours reading it is remarkable for how much it contains. I would recommend the book for students of any discipline, including computer science, casual or professional coders in any programming language. There is a class of reader for whom this book is probably too basic, namely software engineers with a recent academic computer science background.
